G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 28, and 31.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters concerning the minor children pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 19, 28, and 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and applicable case law, including *St. Cyr v. St. Cyr*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 563 (2009).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters concerning the minor children pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 19, 28, and 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and applicable case law, including *St. Cyr v. St. Cyr*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 563 (2009).

*St. Cyr v. St. Cyr*, 75 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: *St. Cyr v. St. Cyr*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 563 (2009)
*St. Cyr v. St. Cyr*, 75 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters concerning the minor children pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 19, 28, and 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and applicable case law, including *St. Cyr v. St. Cyr*, 75 Mass. App. Ct. 563 (2009).
*St. Cyr v. St. Cyr*, 75 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the Probate and Family Court’s continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters under G.L. c. 208 and c. 209C, which govern divorce and nonmarital paternity/custody cases. St. Cyr, however, is a Juvenile Court care-and-protection/guardianship case under G.L. c. 119 and former c. 201 (now c. 190B). Its jurisdictional analysis addresses the interplay between care-and-protection jurisdiction and subsequent guardianship, not continuing jurisdiction under c. 208 or c. 209C. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific continuing-jurisdiction proposition cited.
*St. Cyr v. St. Cyr*, 75 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “These changes do not substantially alter the Probate and Family Court’s jurisdiction over guardianship matters, or the limited circumstances in which the Juvenile Court has concurrent jurisdiction. The newly enacted statute provides: ‘The district or juvenile court may appoint guardians of minors if the person who is the subject of the petition is a minor and there is a proceeding before such district or juvenile court and shall have continuing jurisdiction over resignation, removal, reporting, and other proceedings related to the guardianship.’ G. L. c. 190B, § 5-201.”

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court because the prior Judgment concerning custody and parenting time was issued by this Court, and the parties and children reside within the jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court because the prior Judgment concerning custody and parenting time was issued by this Court, and the parties and children reside within the jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment and that modification is in the best interests of the child.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment and that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct appeal from an initial custody judgment, not a proceeding to modify an existing custody or parenting order. The court discusses standards for making findings about domestic violence and the best interests of the child, but it does not address the threshold requirement for modification (i.e., a material and substantial change in circumstances since a prior judgment). Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: A Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment and that modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion is a direct divorce/custody appeal from an original judgment, not a proceeding to modify an earlier custody or parenting order. The court discusses the best-interests standard and deference to the probate judge’s custody determinations, but it does not articulate or apply a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement for modification of an existing order. Thus, it is not authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that, under the Massachusetts removal statute, the words “upon cause shown” mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and that this is the central question. It further emphasizes that, although the custodial parent’s interests matter, the best interests of the children “always remain the paramount concern,” confirming that the controlling consideration in custody/relocation decisions is the child’s best interests.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.” … “Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the long-standing Massachusetts rule that custody determinations are governed by the best interests of the child, describing this as the central, guiding standard in such cases. The court both traces the historical development of the best‑interests standard and reaffirms that custody awards must be based on what is best for the child, making clear that this is the paramount consideration in custody and parenting-time decisions.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”}

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The Court may modify joint custody arrangements where one parent’s conduct undermines cooperation, communication, and the child’s relationship with the other parent, thereby making joint custody unworkable or contrary to the children’s best interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the standard for removal of children from the Commonwealth when parents share joint legal and physical custody and affirms continued shared custody; it does not involve or endorse modifying joint custody because a parent undermined cooperation or the child’s relationship with the other parent. The court discusses that joint custody requires cooperation and shared decision-making, but it neither finds such cooperation lacking nor orders a change from joint to sole custody on that basis. Thus the case does not provide authority for modifying joint custody under the circumstances described in the proposition.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Although the General Laws state that there is no presumption ‘either in favor or against shared . . . custody at the time of trial on the merits,’ G. L. c. 208, § 31, such an arrangement is generally appropriate only if the parties demonstrate an ability and desire to cooperate amicably and communicate with one another to raise the children. … It is thus incumbent on a parent who has been awarded joint physical custody to recognize that the viability of the endeavor is dependent on his or her ability and willingness to subordinate personal preferences to make the relationship work.”

*Marden v. Marden*, 345 Mass. 505 (1963).proposition: The Court may modify joint custody arrangements where one parent’s conduct undermines cooperation, communication, and the child’s relationship with the other parent, thereby making joint custody unworkable or contrary to the children’s best interests.
*Marden v. Marden*, 345 Mass. 505 (1963).case_name: Leen v. Board of Assessors of Boston
*Marden v. Marden*, 345 Mass. 505 (1963).support_reasoning: This opinion is a tax assessment/administrative law case concerning valuation of property and appellate review of Appellate Tax Board decisions. It does not involve family law, child custody, parental conduct, or the best interests of children, nor does it discuss modification of joint custody arrangements. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about modifying joint custody based on one parent’s undermining conduct.
*Marden v. Marden*, 345 Mass. 505 (1963).relevant_excerpt: Plainly there has not been compliance with Gr. L. c. 30A, § 11 (8). Upon a record of 1110 pages of testimony, in addition to many lengthy exhibits, the tax board has disposed of the vital issue in a single sentence. Not only that, but, enshrouding its finding with a vague reference to “all the evidence,” the board has disposed of that issue in such a way that both the taxpayer and ourselves in attempting to exercise our function of appellate review under Gr. L. c. 30A, § 14 (8), are left without any guide to its reasons.

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Interference with a child’s relationship with the other parent, persistent disparagement, and failure to comply with the spirit of a parenting plan can constitute a material change in circumstances and justify modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a relocation request and a court-imposed temporary change in custody can, by themselves, constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification. The court holds that relocation and the temporary custody shift ordered under § 28A do not qualify, and it does not discuss interference with the child’s relationship with the other parent, disparagement, or failure to honor the spirit of a parenting plan as grounds for modification. Because those specific behaviors are not addressed as a basis for a material change, the opinion does not support the claimed proposition.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… The original judgment awarded sole physical custody to the mother, and ‘must be presumed to have been right.’… There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements…”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Interference with a child’s relationship with the other parent, persistent disparagement, and failure to comply with the spirit of a parenting plan can constitute a material change in circumstances and justify modification.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses general custody principles and the need to base custody decisions on the child’s welfare and a weighing of all relevant factors, but it does not discuss interference with the child’s relationship with the other parent, disparagement, failure to follow a parenting plan, or modification based on a material change in circumstances. Instead, it reverses a custody award because the trial judge appeared to rely on the father’s alleged statutory violation as a punitive basis, without adequate findings on the child’s best interests. Thus it does not establish or affirm the specific proposition claimed.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Interference with a child’s relationship with the other parent, persistent disparagement, and failure to comply with the spirit of a parenting plan can constitute a material change in circumstances and justify modification.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole-legal parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not address post-judgment modification standards, material change in circumstances, or conduct such as disparagement or interference with the other parent’s relationship as grounds for modification. The text is about a judge’s improper use of removal principles (Yannas) in an initial paternity/custody context, not about modification based on interference or noncompliance with a parenting plan.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. … This is not a removal case, and Yannas is inapposite. Neither the judge nor the parties has cited to a single case, from any jurisdiction … that gives a judge authority to pull a parent and child unwillingly back to a State where the parent had a prior and unilateral right to leave.”

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: In evaluating the best interests of the children, the Court considers, among other factors, each parent’s willingness and ability to foster a positive relationship between the children and the other parent, the children’s emotional well-being, stability, the level of parental conflict, and the parties’ ability to communicate and cooperate in child-related matters.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the “best interests of the child” standard in the context of competing adoption placements (aunt vs. foster mother), focusing on factors like the child’s special needs, stability, developmental support, sibling relationships, and the trauma of separation. It does not frame or analyze best interests in terms of each parent’s (or caretaker’s) willingness and ability to foster a positive relationship with the other parent, parental conflict levels, or the adults’ ability to communicate and cooperate in child-related matters. Those coparenting/relational factors between two legal parents are not part of the articulated analysis here, so the case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

*Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 13.proposition: These developments constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the Original Custody Order and warrant modification of the existing custody and parenting provisions to promote the stability, emotional health, and best interests of the minor children.
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 13.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of custody and parenting provisions to promote the children’s stability and best interests. Cooper v. Cooper addresses modification of child support and alimony based on changed financial circumstances and related child needs, not modification of custody or parenting time. While the opinion discusses material changes in circumstances for support, it does not provide authority for modifying custody/parenting provisions as described in the proposition.
*Cooper v. Cooper*, 62 Mass. App. Ct. 13.relevant_excerpt: “In this appeal from a judgment of modification, Philip Cooper also challenges the increased alimony award, claiming that Peggy Cooper, his former wife, failed to establish a material change in circumstances justifying increases in alimony and child support… Here, the probate judge appropriately took into account Philip’s significantly enhanced standard of living since the divorce and changes in the circumstances of the parties that had the effect of reducing the children’s standard of living when residing with Peggy.”
